hints_html:
What is the relation between the given cumulative function F(x) and the probability density function p(x)?

Since

\[\begin{aligned} F(x) = \int_0^x p(s)\,ds\end{aligned}\]

the Fundamental theorem of calculus says that

\[\begin{aligned} F'(x) = p(x).\end{aligned}\]

Hence you are asked to plot the derivative of the given function F(x).
hints_latex:
What is the relation between the given cumulative function \emph{F(x)}
and the probability density function \emph{p(x)}?
hints_raw:
What is the relation between the given cumulative function ''F(x)'' and the probability density function ''p(x)''?
Since

:<math> F(x) = \int_0^x p(s)\,ds </math>

the Fundamental theorem of calculus says that

:<math>\ F'(x) = p(x).</math>

Hence you are asked to plot the derivative of the given function ''F(x)''.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html: The derivative p(x) is zero whenever F(x) is flat, and p(x) is positive whenever F(x) is increasing.
sols_raw:
The derivative ''p(x)'' is zero whenever ''F(x)'' is flat, and ''p(x)'' is positive whenever ''F(x)'' is increasing.

:[[File:Math Exam Resources Courses MATH103 April 2010 Question 3 (a) solution to 3a.png|450px]]
statement_html:
A toxic chemical has been spilled somewhere on a 100 km stretch of highway. The probability that the spill occurred within \(x\) km of the factory is shown in the panel below.

(a) Plot the probability density \(p(x)\) for the location of the spill in the grid provided. (You do not need to provide a scale on the \(y\) axis.)
statement_raw:
A toxic chemical has been spilled somewhere on a 100 km stretch of highway. The probability that the spill occurred within <math>x</math> km of the factory is shown in the panel below.

[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH103_April_2010_Question_3_(a)_picture1_top.png|500px]]

(a) Plot the probability density <math>p(x)</math> for the location of the spill in the grid provided. (You do not need to provide a scale on the <math>y</math> axis.)
